div.head: Thomas Churchyarde to the Reader.
div.l: JF still my pen in silence slept, when wit the world awakes,
And willing mynds with weary workes, great toyle & trauel takes:
My frendes might think I had forgot to honour learned men,
And dulled spirites did daintie waxe, through piuish slouth of Pen.
Wherfore though simple sight I haue in Bathes & boiling Springs,
I prayse the head that here vnfoulds, the force of secrete things
Though sundry sercht by iudgements deepe, to hit the marke before,
At rouers they but shot theyr Shafts, and dribbed wyde a skore.
For Bathes did breede an heape of doubts, and few disclosed the same,
Till he that wrote this skilfull booke, a forme therof did frame,
And tells vs how, and when we ought, to vse the Bathes a right,
Which frutes who skornes to know and keepe, is blind of sence & sight.
And seeking help he findeth harme, yea sometimes death withall,
As doth the young babe that warmes his hand and so in fyre fall.
Or as a chyld in sommer tyme seeking his thyrst to coole,
Doth slip vnwares down cruel streams, & drowns him self in poole.
So men that seeke for medicine sweete, may sometime myschef finde,
If they obserue not seasons due, to take eche thing in kinde.
I wade no further in this case, read what doth follow heere,
And robbe no spark of fame from him, that makes these douts so cleere
Who thinks this labour well bestowed if thou therby mayst gaine,
Or if in busie babling world, his works may shape disdaine.
